1.content:
Prom-otion or Demotion?
A high school senior having the time of his life at prom night gets quite the shock the next day when he finds out the day hasn't changed! Not only that, but he seems to have gotten younger!

Mission Unpossible
Samus Aran goes through a typical day with a pretty simple mission. But when an anomaly causes her to experience the mission over and over, changes to her body and mind make it harder to complete each time...

Repetitive Content
A gaming fanatic finally manages to get through that difficult challenge, only to discover their progress never saves! They keep trying to complete it, not realizing that each time they start becoming more and more like their in-game character...

(Poke)monster Girls
You're a Pokemon Trainer who's finally managed to beat the Elite Four and become Champion! Except you keep waking to a world where it hasn't happened yet. Even stranger, your Pokemon seem to be getting a little more...humanoid?
1.title: Choice: What Deja Vu Scenario?

choices: To stay human, at the expense of your god
13.content:
âDonât choke now... please... god... let me be finished...l
The grind was nearly over. Samâs character was making the same motions with nearly exactly the same timing as the last attempt, and the one before that. Each press of the keyboard was refined to a science, to the point where Sam could feel intuitively the actions of the protagonist. He had spent ever hour of his free time for the past six days looking at the heroineâs back, to the point where real life seemed to fade away.âroll here, wait a second... align the camera to the fourth stripe in the wall, and here we go. After this is 3 minutes of non stop panic. Following my failure, thereâs another ten minutes to get back here, assuming I donât fuck things up again, in which case I will need to reload my save, and thatâs going to tack on another 20.â. Sam takes a deep breath. Itâs the last one heâll take before his defeat. Probably something stupid this time around. A misclick. A badly preformed roll. Falling off the cliff the devs decided to put smack dab in the middle of the arena.âWelp, here goesâ

          For the first phase of the boss, everything went smoothly. There was an easily identifiable rhythm that he had at this point master. When the right arm goes up, backstep. When the left arm goes up, side step toward the attack. When both arms go up, sprint through the giants legs. Each successful dodge gives you enough time to make one attack. Of course, if you had invested early on in ranged attacks, the whole fight is already finished. But alas, here he was, chipping away at the boss with his meager short sword, because his lightning spear did next to no damage to unarmored enemies. After about 10 minutes wasted hacking away, the boss entered the second phase. The phase where Sam had died 2,000 times.

         the second phase of the boss is pure Rng. While Sam has beaten bosses ranked as fans as much harder, the element of randomness left him despondent. However, today, luck seemed to be on his side. He got three easy attacks in a row, and, having used the majority of his consumables, ended the fight with relative ease. âfinallyâ sam wheeled back and watched the prerendered cutscene. âThis is itâ he said, skipping through all the dialogue lines. He went to the npc to claim his end credits...
And the npc gave him a choice prompt. âThe time is how or never, Scarlet. The choice is yours, will you follow your ancestors and claim the giant-heart, or retain your humanity, at the expense of-
Sam skipped the dialogue. âWho cares, I already won. Just get me to the new game+â I need to try lightning spear on the tutorial boss. He selected the first option, which was
13.title: Repetitive Content

choices: Don’t want to come up with a title
131.content:
Instead of the game returning to the main menu, however, it loaded from the last save point. “That’s fine, It should give me the option to start a new game+ when I restart.” It didn’t. Sam nearly rage quits, but quickly calms down. “It’s alright. I’ve done this before. At this point, I can practically breathe along with scarlet. I’ve mastereed this section”. Perhaps boosted by this confidence, he is able to complete the entire pathway to the boss without difficulty. Bizarrely enough, now that the boss had been completed once, Sam found it easy to repeat again. But as he went skipping through the final cutscene once more, the same thing happened. Not even restarting it allowed access to completion.

Sam tried again and again, and was now beating the boss every time. He could began mimicking Scarlet’s grunts whenever he rolled, to ease the boredom. But nothing would change, the game refused to be won. It felt like each grunt from scarlet was mocking him rather than the opposite, the game knowingly forcing him to listen to the same audio clips over and over again. Sam was stuck like this. Able to beat the final section by heart, yet unable to claim its rewards. “What could I possibly be doing wrong”
131.title: To stay human,at the expense of your god

choices: Just Another Day on the Job
15.content:
Ultimate Insanity
The Smash Bros. universe gets increasingly absurd as strange changes hit the contestants during a tournament, getting weirder with each iteration.

Just Another Day on the Job
A businessman must learn to adjust to their ever-changing office environment on the day of an important meeting.

Twitch Reaction
An online streamer can't seem to earn the subscribers he wants, even when he breaks world records. But when he starts repeating the day over with more feminine changes, will he be able to hit it big?

EK-OMG!
A nurse has a hard time dealing with her patients as they become less human and more supernatural.
15.title: Choice: More Deja Vu Scenarios

choices: A strange DM on his streaming site. What kind of a name is DeusEstMachina?
A weird light filtering through his blinds.
A thumping at his apartment door.
153.content:
“Ughruff.”

The less than dignified grunt of effort signified Zachary Morrison’s final freight of the day and the completion of his not-explicitly-but-definitely-implicitly-required overtime. He wiped the sweat off his brow with the back of his hand. Lifting five sixty-pound boxes was a task in and of itself, but putting them on the third shelf — that was a goddamn ordeal.

A heavy weight fell on his shoulder, sending him whirling back to meet a face that seemed to be mostly smile, besides the coiff of blonde hair framing its top. It was Kevin, his senior at work and age, by one year and three years respectively.

“Damn good job, Zach,” he remarked, striding around the storage room. “You’re strong as hell, man.”

Zach’s head jerked up and down in brief acknowledgment. “Thanks.”

“You sure you don’t wanna work the register, man? It’s way easier than lugging all this stuff around.”

“Nah, I’m good. Dealing with customers is a bit—”

“..easy.” finished Kevin. “Just give people their change and ask the old ladies how their day was, and you don’t have to break your back for two hours.”

Zach rolled his shoulders and winced slightly. “I’m not that much of a people person, I guess.”

They meandered to the clock card system, both fishing their respective cards out.

“I suppose not being a ‘people person’ means you don’t wanna get drinks with me and some other guys?” asked Kevin. “Buffalo Wild Wings, forty minutes.”

“I’m also not a… drinks guy.” Zach swiped his card in the ancient machine, which chugged for a good four seconds before inking the appropriate rectangle. “And, it’s Friday, so I —”

“It’s cool, it’s cool.” Kevin raised his hands in the air in placation. “Just floating it out there.”

“Yeah, thanks for that.”

The vaguely awkward silence persisted as they both shed their uniforms and meandered towards the staff exit.

“See you later, Kev.”

“You too, Zach.”

Something inside Zach twisted itself into a knot of guilt. It wasn’t that Kevin wasn’t a good guy, it was just that he.. well..

~~~

“Heyoo, everyone, Zee-Gamer here with ya! god i really need to change that name"

… had better things to do.

Well, not better, per se, just things he wanted to do more. He wanted to return to his kingdom of LCD displays and wires, his 52’window into a different world. He wanted to stream.

Streaming served to destree and excite, all without the fuss-and-muss of face-to-face interaction. He had been particularly interesgtd by the speedrunning section of the internet and even amassed a couple WRs of his own on some logging sites. There was just one big problem.

Zach took a peek at his recording monitor. The value he was looking for was on the bottom right: Viewers: 2.

One of them was him, and the other was his bot.

Shit.

His pained wince was quickly replaced with a bright smile, not that it mattered; he didn’t even have a face cam. It's not like he was expecting a larger number, he was just hoping for one.

No matter. The show must go on.

“Alright, so tonight we’ll be running Bepisman.” He shuffled through some papers he had on his desk. “It’s an ad-game parody, but it’s pretty tightly made, so there’ll be less glitch-skips than normal.”

The screen lit up with the unskippable intro cutscene: Bepisman looking forlornly into the horizon where his erstwhile paramour — Lady Ocke — was overlaid, clutching a billowing hankie to her forehead in an eternal swoon.

“Yeah, so, um, the MC is named Bepisman because of Pepsi, and the girl’s Ocke because of Coke..."

Shit, he was mumbling again. He snuck a peek at the count again: 4 viewers! Nice!

“The game’s a neat mix of Ghost and Goblins and, uh, the Persona games, I guess. You’ll see the second part in a bit.”

He navigated Bepisman through the halls of Castle Bepis with alacrity, only stopping at a short, rotund man who bore a striking resemblance to a grain mascot.

“So this is Earl Quaker, and normally I wouldn’t talk to any NPCs, but you have to sit through all of his dialogue if you want the end game weapon early, so, uh, buckle in, I guess. NPC’s have amechanics that are ”
He hit the TALK button and started mashing it, skipping through the entirety of the geezer’s dialogue. Still, it took a good two minutes, during which his eyes were glued to the chat.

GreatGazoolie: lol wtf is this ResidentSleeper game

firegirl426: shutup i like the pixel art

“Yeah, this part is a little boring, Gazoolie, sorry.” Zach nervously chuckled. “And yeah, Firegirl, I like the art too. There’s a lotta heart in the game.”

GreatGazoolie: LUL u just got kaepora’d

firegirl426: look at the screen <:o

Zach’s eyes shot back to the screen. Shit. The earl’s dialogue reached a “Would you like me to repeat that?” and he accidentally hit ‘Yes’.

“Oops. Uh, sorry, chat.”

~~~

The rest of the evening didn’t go better than that. People flitted in and out of the chat (mostly out), some leaving messages of encouragement, and some leaving less than-encouraging messages. Those stuck in his mind.

zomgcopter: LUL is this prerecorded? hes not talkin at all

kripyatgmr: does this dood have fisher price router? its like im watching JPG slideshow

XxnubletronxX: do u have a schedule? or r these streams just random?

Zach took the brief time afforded during another unskippable cutscene to grimace. They each had a point: He was focusing a bit too much on the game to interact with chat, if he even spoke at all! The last ten minutes had consisted of relieved sighs on successful skips and pained groans whenever RNG screwed him.

Taking a look at his desk revealed His setup was a ramshackle nest of cords and HDMI cables with a dollar-store capture card. He could probably skim some money from his budget to upgrade one thing or another, but he’d be eating ramen for a couple of weeks if he tried that.

The last comment was a bit on-the-nose. His streams were spontaneous and highly conditional: he had to have enough time and energy after work to try one. Fridays usually were ‘The Day’ but even that wasn’t consistent. Some stammered half-response would have to do for an answer

An hour later, Zach zero to death’d the boss with a grimace on his face. There were only 3 people left in the chat — GreatGazoolie and firegirl had shot him a follow before leaving, fortunately — and he was on time to set a new record.

“‘s not like anyone’s gonna watch some nobody play a fangame...” he grumbled. Sure it was what he wanted to do, but it wasn’t gonna grow his fanbase. He clicked the split timer on its final subdivision.

2:11:04. New world record. Thrilling.

“Alright guys… Er, guy, I guess. Sorry for the bellyaching, but I’m winding down the stream for tonight.”

No response from chat. Typical.

Zach shut down the recording software and streaming portal with knit eyebrows and a sputtering of air from pursed lips. Sure, he wasn’t expecting to get, like, front-page big in six months’ time, but, y’know, getting at least double-digit’s’d be nice.

He set records! He beat times on games that were actually played! That had to count for something!

But despite his supplication to a sense of fairness in the world, ten people did not subscribe to him on the spot.

He stared up at the ceiling and groaned. If only something could change.

Zach was drawn from his ‘woe-is-me’ soliloquy by…
153.title: Twitch Reaction

choices: “Why do you want to be popular?”
“What sets you apart from other streamers?”
“What do you want your audience to like about you?”
1531.content:
A boop from Zach’s computer drew his attention away from his doom-spiraling. Someone had posted something in his chat that was, evidently, not as dead as he thought.

He squinted at the message; it was from some user called ‘DeusEstMachina’, which had to be one of the more pretentious names he had seen on the site.

Zach raised a host of emotional walls in preparation for the message, a precaution that his bruised ego insisted was necessary. If this jamoke saved a message for after the dream, it had to be something particularly vitriolic…

DeusEstMachina: GROW YOUR VIEWERBASE FOR **FREE** BY END OF TOMORROW PROMISED!! CLICK HERE:

And then a shortened URL. Zach frowned. This was almost worse. Scratch that, this was worse; there’d be no emotional catharsis of banning some jerk, just the sad, sad Old-Yeller-ing of a spambot. Shouldn’t the auto-admin take care of this?

“At least it’s my first one,” Zach mumbled, aiming his cursor over the offending message, bringing up the almighty drop-down menu...

And then he fatfingered the link.

“Oh goddammit,” moaned the streamer aspirant as various tabs opened and closed like a series of possessed doors. He brought out the big guns quickly: ctrl+alt+shift-ing Task Manager open before anything bad could happen —

Download manager pop-up. Uh oh. File explorer was accessed immediately, but the file — temporalcircuit.exe — wouldn’t budge for anything, not even the almighty delete function. Sighing, Zach went to get a drink of water as his antivirus puttered to life.

He only got five steps away from his desks and four seconds into another session of self-pity before the error noise rang out so loud he could hear it from his headphones.

Shit.

Zach negotiated the five steps’ distance as quickly as he could without stumbling over the rapunzel-length bundle of cords stemming from his computer. He reached for his headphones from instinct, but stopped himself right before he put them on which saved him a visit to the doctor; considering the volume of the muzak that shot out of the things.

A purple window sat in the middle of his screen, bright clashing yellow letters reading ‘POPULAR MAKER ONE DAY GUARANTEE’, a neon green button labeled ‘START’ beneath it.

Zach grimaced as hard as he could. This screamed malware. Poorly written, kill-your-computer malware. He tried to click away, but once again, the error noise blared out even louder than the music. Task-manager was once again accessed, but it bounced off the program like a sword off plate-mail.

“Whaddya mean, ‘Process cannot be ended,’?” Zach grumbled, furiously clicking the useless button. He leaned over the keyboard to his streaming laptop — to hopefully find a solution that didn’t involve bricking his tower — but the enter key must’ve been pressed somehow, because a chime rang out from his discarded headphones, loud as Big Ben.

He jerked back to the recesses of his uncomfortable chair with a grunt, followed shortly after by a groan. The janky ‘START’ screen had vanished and been replaced by another window, headed by ‘EZ ONE-STEP QUESTION ANSWER’ in the same yellow-on-purple vomit aesthetic.

Zach set his face into hard lines. This… felt like a lost cause. The broken-english .exe in front of him clearly wasn’t going to go, and it probably would’ve ransomed his data five minutes before if it was going to do that. Maybe this was some weird esoteric data-gathering program that just happened to look like the bad kind.

He might as well give it a shot — the reckless move partially motivated by the fact that his phone and laptop didn’t seem to be responding to his desperate pleas for search-engine access.

Surprisingly, the purple program in front of him had a lot of questions written in disparately competent English to choose from. Like, scroll-down-for-five-minutes a lot. Whenever a question was clicked on, a weird multiple-choice was brought up with equally manifold examples.

Weird was definitely the word for it, he considered.

Brow still knit in slight concern, Zach scrolled at random and selected the query…
1531.title: Multiple-Choice Malware?

15313.content:
“What do you want your audience to like about you?”

Even though Zach had just happened to choose that particular question, it made him think a little more than usual. If it had been something like 'Why do you want to be popular?' it would've been a no-brainer. To make a decent amount of money, have a decent quality of life with the hobby he enjoyed evolving into a full-time career, and to have a decent ego boost from having his name mentioned on different online communities. Maybe someday he'd even get the honor of being in one of those speedrunning compilations of a particularly beloved title, finally setting a new world record after having mastered every technique, every exploit, every oversight the game had to offer.

But this question? It wasn't really something Zach had been anticipating. He was somewhat lucky that there were pre-determined answers in front of him rather than a free response box. Otherwise it was 50/50 as to whether he'd actually write a meaningful answer that made use of all the allotted characters or just type in 'idk' and call it a day. He started looking over the options available to him:

My looks. Becoming the kind of streamer that people want to stick around for isn't always easy. That being said, your genetics definitely gave you an early advantage, allowing people to come for the content and stay for the lingering questions in their head like 'What's this knockout doing playing video games all alone on a Friday night?'

Some air went through his nose a little quicker than usual as he found the idea quite humorous. "That's exactly it; I got into the speedrunning game so people could stare at my Adonis-like features. This program really does get me!" He hadn't even really considered the use of a webcam up until now- his rather introverted nature assumed people would flock to his channel solely for the gaming content, rather than watching the man behind the scenes. "I guess if I really was that easy on the eyes it'd probably be worth it, but as is no one's going to care what some random 6/10 nobody looks like while running through Bubble Bobble."

My raw talent. Despite the presence of so many fish in the ever-expanding sea of gaming videos, you managed to break from the pack and stand out. Could it be your penchant for finding new ways to break a game? Or maybe your complete dedication to avoiding mistakes in your runs? Either way, you seem to bring that special something to every one of your streams, and your fans know it.

"I want to believe that's true, but..." Zach seemed a little dejected. He wasn't the type to discover new exploits on his own, so that was an unlikely avenue of success. And at the end of the day, it would be silly to say that he was one of the best speedrunners in the world right now. If he was, surely he'd already be famous, right? Besides, how much did being talented matter if he never branched out from the niche games he admittedly was so fond of?

My personality. Your gaming prowess was never really the way to popularity for you. Rather, it's your ability to be down-to-earth that your audience finds appealing. You listen to feedback, and give the people what they want. No bullshit, just a friendly all-around wholesome (albeit a bit awkward) person, inviting others to come together as a community with a mutual love for gaming. When fans have told you that they basically considered you a friend, you didn't even bat an eye.

"If only it was that easy," Zach scoffed. It sounded to him an apt description of 80% of streamers as a whole. Getting popular on personality alone seemed virtually impossible without being either A) exceedingly lucky or B) an eccentric that people came to stare at in awe and confusion. Not having to develop a fake persona just to grow interest in his streams was certainly more desirable, though.

"What's with some of these descriptions anyway? Feels like I'm doing character customization for Twitch Simulator 2020," Zach questioned. Regardless, he knew he should pick something in the hopes of getting this damned program off his computer. After some internal deliberation, he finally moused over...
15313.title: The Key to Streaming Success

155.content:
Anime Logic, Now Reality
An otaku's life turns into quite the experience as his day repeats, each time becoming more and more like an anime.

Always a Bridesmaid...
A wedding day goes awry for a bride when she finds her reliving the moment, but as a bridesmaid! Who's the new bride?!
155.title: Choice: Even More Deja Vu Scenarios!

info.brief_description: Scenarios where a character keeps reliving an experience (with some changes each time).
info.description:
Think a Groundhog Day type situation but with TFs involved. The repeated event doesn't have to be an entire day, though! Reality changes optional.

The only real rule is that you need some type of event/day repeated. Whether that event takes place over one, a couple, or many chapters is your choice! Feel free to change how the event occurs (or what happens that day) based on what changes occur each time, but it should be obvious that the characters are stuck in some kind of weird time loop (whether they are aware of it or not is up to you). Otherwise, be as broad as you want with the theme!

I'll award GP for high-quality additions that are at least 200 words.
